thread.title: Mom at Port Clinton park calls 9-1-1 after finding abandoned backpack: “There is a dead dog in it”
thread.title_full: Mom at Port Clinton park calls 9-1-1 after finding abandoned backpack: “There is a dead dog in it”

author: 13abc
title: Mom at Port Clinton park calls 9-1-1 after finding abandoned backpack: “There is a dead dog in it”
text:
PORT CLINTON (13abc Action News) – A family taking a Sunday walk in the park stumbles upon a disturbing discovery that even left a 9-1-1 operator gasping in shock.
The West End Community Park in Port Clinton is not a crime scene.
What happened in the garbage can along the basketball court is not against the law.
But some say it’s disgusting.
"It's very cruel,” says Matt Ritter who lives in Port Clinton. “It's disrespectful. I'm a dog lover myself. I couldn't imagine doing something like that. It's insane."
A Port Clinton police sergeant, whose partner is K-9 officer Spike, is upset over what was found inside an abandoned backpack.
"Me, personally, I would bury the dog in as humane a manner as possible,” says Sgt. Joshua Nelson.
Last Sunday a mom, dad, and their children were taking a walk in the newly renovated park when their dog started sniffing the trash can.
40-year-old Amanda Miller of Fremont says her dog wouldn’t leave it alone.
She called 9-1-1: “My husband decided to look in and there is a backpack in there. He said it was awfully heavy so I told him to check it out. There is a dead dog in it.”
The 9-1-1 Operator gasped and said, “Oh my God.”
Someone put a deceased dog in a backpack and left it in the garbage can of the West End Park where children play on the playground and basketball court.
Nelson says it was a small silver, black and brown collie or sheep dog mix without a collar or tag.
"It didn't look like anybody had used any sort of weapons on the dog,” says Nelson. “To me it looked like the dog died of natural causes and they disposed of it in there."
Nelson says police tried to contact the dog warden and humane society. But when they didn’t hear anything back, Nelson says he disposed of the body in the dumpster behind the police department.
"That way no children could see him,” says Nelson. “No passerby could see him."
Nelson says it is not against the law to dump a deceased dog in the trash. He says it’s simply a poor moral decision to put the body in a public park.
